title: Breath of the Mangroves
description: At the fringe where Thassyl’s bone-arched lanes taper into a hush of roots and brackish breath, the Whisper Mangroves draw their fog about them like a shawl stitched with secrets. The Lumin Weavers have gathered with nacre-masked pilgrims and tired children who cradle living lanterns, each flame a careful promise against waters that remember. Asha Heliope’s hands are steady as she knots prayer-threads to braziers tuned to breathe with the tide, but the air around her tastes of salt and copper, and her eyes skim the dark places where whispers collect. Reed-ropes have been found slyly knotted across channels, a cheap malice meant to trip the unwary and fracture the procession’s shining line, and rumor says a false chorus rides the fog with a grief that tugs at the ribs. Kael Rimestrand is called to the front as a heron is called to shallow water, to read the glyphs of wind and mud, to lead the light along safe roots, to gather the good spores without waking nests, to pull back any pilgrim the whispers would steal, and to catch the names the mangroves exhale so the Fathom Tongues can answer with a truer song before the Unshelling draws half the city to the tide’s lip. The night will be beautiful in the way a blade can be beautiful, and the first sound of it is the soft tut of bone-eels turning in their knots beneath the roots.
objectives: Meet Asha Heliope at the Weavers’ Cloister near the Whisper Mangroves.
Escort the lumen procession along the mapped white-heron path to the Sanctum of the First Shell.
Gather a pouch of healthy lumenkelp spores from the seedbeds without disturbing root-nests.
Rescue any pilgrim lured by stray whispers off the safe path and return them to the procession.
Record the names the mangroves whisper on a brine-ink slip and deliver it to Tern Quietwake at the Thalassarium.

dialogue.speaker: Asha Heliope
dialogue.lines: You still carry the sea in your shoulders, Kael Rimestrand, and I hear it in the hush between your breaths when you look toward black water that wants remembering. Tonight we thread the mangroves with living light, and I will not cede one child to fog that pretends to be a mother’s voice. Look there, where the reeds are too neat for chance and the fray is fresh, someone has been knotting snares that would turn grief into a harvest. Walk with us and give the lanterns a spine to lean on, because a steady back is louder than a bell when the mist begins to lie. If the grove speaks names, write them in brine and keep your hand from shaking, even if it writes my own, and I will pay for the ink with the last of my patience before I pay with blood.

dialogue.speaker: Kael Rimestrand
dialogue.lines: I’ve walked these roots since I had fewer scars and more foolish songs, and I’ve learned which mud drinks a boot and which mud only kisses the heel. I’ll read the lean of the wind and the lay of the roots and keep to the white heron’s line, because the bird steps straight when the world tries to tilt. If a voice borrows my mother’s shape or your own breath, I will hold my rope like it is an oath and answer no summons that is not a sign we agreed upon. I’ll count our lights at every bend, pull the ones who wander back into the body of the procession, and leave no glow drifting where hunger might notice. When the grove exhales its names, I’ll catch them on ink and keep them where the tide can’t wash them away until the Tongues have a chance to make that sound mean mercy instead of debt.

dialogue.speaker: Sirae Glowhand
dialogue.lines: I’ve tuned the braziers to breathe with the turn so the flames will bow when the tide does and rise again when the pull eases, and their glass bellies won’t crack even if the fog licks cold. If the false chorus pushes, I can dim the lanterns to a ghost-glow so our eyes can find your hand signs and we can slip where a shout would break us. I don’t like the way these reed-ends smell of new knife and old fear, which means this is theater more than murder, but theater scares better than teeth when night is thick. I’ve told the children that a lantern is a promise that does not wander and a promise that wanders becomes a lure, and they understood in the way that makes me ache. If your hand lifts twice I’ll hold the line still, if your hand turns I’ll pull them inward, and if your hand is not there then I’ll put my own where yours should be and pray the heron forgives me.

dialogue.speaker: Pilgrim Child
dialogue.lines: The trees are whispering a name and it sounds like a shell scraping smooth, and it sounds like the lullaby that made my bones remember their shape when the storm took our roof. I hear it behind my ear where only my mother’s breath should go, and it says there is a warm place with a light like soup and laughter if I just step where the mud is sweet. I want to see the white heron step because everyone says it walks on water without sinking, and I think if I see it I will know how to walk home even if the street is gone. My shell is shaking a little and I don’t want the shaking to mean I am weak or wicked, I only want it to mean I am alive and someone will hold my hand if I ask. Will you show me where your feet go, and tell the whispers to wait until morning when I am not so small.

dialogue.speaker: Asha Heliope
dialogue.lines: The fog is beginning to thread itself into strings, and that is how liars pretend to be harps, so we will cut what can be cut and step around what cannot. Keep the rope low, keep the lanterns high, and remember that panic is a current that grabs ankles first and drags heads second. Whoever set these knots meant to make fear do their work because fear will stir faster than water and spill more cups without showing its hands. Kael, take one of the cleaner snares for my loom mothers so they can read the make and the haste of the knotter, and leave the rest tasting of our knives so the setter knows their theater has an audience that does not clap. Children, breathe with the tide, not with the whispers, because the sea gives a rhythm for free and lies always charge interest at the end.

dialogue.speaker: Tern Quietwake
dialogue.lines: You carried light through the grove’s green breath without letting a single promise drift loose into black water, and the sound of it is in your shoulders now like a deep drum that will take a while to fade. I will take your slips of brine-ink and lay them on the cool stone where echoes keep their shape, and I will ask the trench for a chord that answers names without calling bodies down. If there is a debt moving toward us I will bargain to break it into smaller coins that grief can pay slowly, and if there is malice I will seek the mouth that sang it and make that mouth taste its own pitch. The whispers you heard carry a fragment of a song that is not a whale’s and not a god’s, and that is a poor kind of music that fools listen to until their lungs forget to breathe. Go rest your ears and let your backbone unclench, because you will be asked to stand straight again soon, and a spine that never bows will crack when the tide insists.

choices.title: Cut the knots and pass like a heron
choices.text: You signal for silence and draw the procession inward until the line is tight as a braided cord, then you take your knife and speak to the reeds with patient teeth. Every snare you find you sever at the heart and leave the ends ragged, not to gloat, but to tell the setter that their stage has been struck without an audience. You move with the tide’s breath, stepping where the heron would step, ignoring the sweet pull of voices that pretend to be kin and letting the children match your feet until their fear runs out of road. When you reach the seedbeds you kneel with deliberate hands, gather healthy lumenkelp spores that glow like soft promises, and ease the root-nests back into their hush without waking a single eel. All the while you count the lanterns, keep the rope low, and write the grove’s names in brine between breaths so the fog cannot smudge them.
choices.outcome: The procession arrives at the Sanctum of the First Shell unbroken and humming with the quiet pride that follows a hard crossing, and the children’s masks tilt with drowsy relief instead of grief. Asha sees the saved snare and reads the haste and the petty cruelty in its knots, and she praises patience over spectacle, vowing to let her loom mothers trace the fibers back to the hands that tied them. The Weavers pledge you a glow tithe favor without bargaining, and their sanctuaries open to your step at night as if you had always belonged to their watch. Tern Quietwake accepts your brine-ink names and hums a counterchord you can feel in your teeth, promising to guard the Unshelling with warnings tuned to truth rather than fear. The saboteur remains in shadow for now, but they feel the weight of being watched, and the city whispers begin to shift toward gratitude, which is a quieter wind that sets fewer fires.

choices.title: Set an ambush at the reed snares
choices.text: Rather than cut and pass, you post Sirae to hold the lantern line steady while you arrange a crescent of shadow around the freshest knot, your hand signals slow as tide so no heart runs ahead of breath. You dust the reeds with a pinch of lumen spores so the first fingers that reach for the rope will glow, not to blind, but to mark, and you wait with your bow half-drawn and your patience whole. The whispers scratch at the back of your ear and try on your mother’s voice twice, then your captain’s once, and each time you inhale and let the sound slide off the part of you that is all string and arrow. When the footsteps come they are light and guilty, and the silhouettes that slip between the roots wear novice masks carved too clean to be old, their hands shaking more from borrowed zeal than hunger. You close the trap with a single word only your people know, the rope rises like a question, and the would-be saboteurs fall into your keeping with more apologies than answers.
choices.outcome: Under the lanterns’ pale authority, the ambushed knotters are revealed as overzealous vow-children from the Children of the First Shell, tutored by a faceless whisper-note that promised them the sea would love them more if they shamed the Weavers into humility. Asha’s anger is hot but brief, and she cools it in a bowl of water before turning it into work, sending a runner to Mother Tullis with a request for discipline rather than vengeance, because vengeance can be taught but discipline must be chosen. The procession is delayed but not broken, and you still harvest a pouch of healthy spores with careful hands, though the tide’s turn forces you to take a swifter cut back to the white heron path. The marked novices, cowed and blinking, help carry lanterns the rest of the way and learn how weight feels when it is shared rather than thrown, and some of their shame dissolves into duty before dawn. Tern Quietwake receives your list of names and the story of the false instruction, and promises to listen for the shadow-teacher’s pitch among the city’s rumor-tide, while the Weavers’ favor and access are granted without a chisel put to the terms, and your purse is pressed with coin that tastes of honest salt.

choices.title: Follow the false chorus into the fog
choices.text: You hand the lead rope to Sirae Glowhand with a nod that says trust louder than any oath, and you slip sideways through the mangrove’s whispering teeth, chasing the thread of song that pulls like grief. Every few paces you set a brine glyph with your heel so your path is a ledger you can read backward if the fog decides to trim your memory. The chorus swells and then thins like breath through a split reed, and you notice how it snags on certain roots and hums where no throat should be, which is the trick of resonant stones strung in branches by hands that have walked these paths with maps. You find the little bells of echo-stone tied beneath leaves, cut three with a careful knife, and let one sing by your ear while you sketch the intervals in your ledger so the Tongues will know the counterfeit from the whale. When you return to the procession you are a little colder and a little saltier, but you are intact and you have proof wrapped in cloth instead of only suspicion wrapped in pride.
choices.outcome: Sirae has kept the line safe and still, her palms white at the rope but her eyes steady, and the pilgrims look at you as if your shadow knows a way home that their feet can learn. You harvest the lumenkelp spores quickly and gently, using the echo-bells you captured to soothe a skittish eel back into its hole so your fingers return without toothmarks. The return along the white heron’s path is faster than it feels, because your shoulders carry a new map of danger and that makes the mud seem less hungry for your boots. At the Sanctum, Asha wraps your captured stones in silk and thanks you with a tired laugh that sounds like a lamp catching, while Tern Quietwake places one echo-bell against the Thalassarium’s tooth and grimaces at the sour counterfeit the stones repeat. The Weavers honor their promised favor and access, coin clinks into your palm, and a quiet understanding spreads through your allies that someone is trying to teach the city to drown by humming the wrong notes in the ears of the faithful, which means your work will have a second night to it soon.

rewards.description: 400 experience, earned for guiding the procession, gathering spores, rescuing the wayward, and carrying the grove’s names to the Thalassarium without losing a single light.
Lumenbraid Wrist-Wrap: a woven band that softly steadies the pulse and sharpens night-navigation, lending calm to panicked companions when your hand finds theirs.
Pouch of Healthy Lumen Spores: a carefully sealed sachet for future rites, bright with patient promise and untouched by muddied roots.
Glow tithe from the Lumin Weavers: one ward’s worth of living light at your command during a risky undertaking, no questions asked and no ledger scratched.
Open doors at Weavers’ sanctuaries after dusk, allowing passage, rest, and quiet counsel without need of escort or countersign.
20 credit-shells, their edges brined and honest, pressed into your palm at journey’s end.
